results.title: Integrated curriculum
results.creator_credit: Jeff Spencer, Lily Steiner, Chris O'Rourke and Victoria. Schools Division. Curriculum Branch
results.brief_description: Shows how an integrated curriculum can operate in classrooms with children ranging from preparatory to years five and six. It shows how different areas of the curriculum can be integrated to promote learning.

results.title: Correction procedures
results.brief_description: Demonstrates and provides correction techniques used when assessing written work to provide immediate feedback on children’s progress. Shows how to diagnose incorrect responses by response type, how to recognize the type of error and three basic correction procedures.
results.description: Demonstrates and provides correction techniques used when assessing written work to provide immediate feedback on children’s progress. Shows how to diagnose incorrect responses by response type, how to recognize the type of error and three basic correction procedures.

results.title: The Matrix reloaded [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Lana Wachowski, Lilly Wachowski, Joel Silver, Warner Bros Pictures, Village Roadshow Pictures, Silver Pictures and NPV Entertainment
results.brief_description: Can Neo save Morpheus, Trinity, the community of Zion and himself from the evil machinations of the Matrix? Find out in this sequel to the spectacularly successful “The Matrix” - a film which rewrote the terms and references (re-appropriating Hong Kong kung-fu flicks) of the action/sci-fi genre. In this instalment the residents of Zion receive news of an imminent invasion; controversially the crew of the Nebuchadnezzar (Neo et al) decamp to see the Oracle and perhaps fulfil the prophecy - that the One will deliver salvation to all. The action components of this film are entirely satisfying - witness an unforgettably awesome freeway chase scene; Neo combating multiple Agent Smiths; Trinity’s balletic death-defying leap; and Neo’s speed flights across time and space. But whilst the technical ingenuity enthralls, the narrative is only sporadically comprehensible with an increasingly portent tone, dabbling as it does in quasi-religiosity (check out Neo’s fetching monastic robes), tribalism, biblical and mythic traditions. Detrimentally the dialogue is often uselessly cryptic, obfuscating narrative progression, which in itself is stymied by dead-end threads and ill explained interactions. But that still leaves what the Wachowskis do so well - clever wirework, CGI and bullet-time slow motion - in other words, action aplenty. And be assured that “Reloaded” has that in spades.

results.title: Fair go!
results.creator_credit: Open Channel Productions and Victorian Trades Hall Council
results.brief_description: Fair go! is a step towards meeting the needs of young people for information about their rights as workers. Using a fresh, entertaining presentation, the program follows the experiences of school-leavers Kelly and Sam, as they fall unawares into a series of near disasters in new jobs.

results.title: Osmose
results.brief_description:
Osmose (1995) is an immersive virtual environment with real-time display of 3D computer graphics and interactive 3D localized sound. The interface consists of a head-mounted display and real-time motion tracking based on breath and balance. There are a dozen world-spaces in Osmose, most based on metaphorical aspects of nature. Immersants are able to journey anywhere within these worlds, as well as hover in the ambiguous transition areas.

The first realm encountered is a three-dimensional Cartesian grid which functions as an orientation space. With the immersant’s first breaths, this grid gives way to a clearing, surrounded by forest. It is possible to enter the clearing’s single tree and the interior of its leaves, float through the never-ending forest, or descend into subterranean depths among translucent roots and rocks. One can also sink through the pond into an oceanic abyss, or rise above the clearing into cloud. Two additional realms function as conceptual parentheses around the work: the substratum Code located below the underearth, which contains much of the actual software used to create the work; and the superstratum Text, located above the cloud, consisting of excerpts of relevant texts on technology, the body and nature.

The sounds in Osmose were sampled from a male and female voice uttering phonetics, then digitally processed and localized in three-dimensions. The sound is generated on the fly, in real time, responding like the visuals to changes in the immersant’s head and body position, direction and speed. After fifteen minutes of immersion, a symbolic life-world appears and then irretrievably recedes, bringing the session to an end.

Osmose was so named for “osmosis” from “osmos” (Greek) “to push”; a biological process involving passage from one side of a semi-permeable cellular membrane to another. Osmose, as metaphor, is about longing: for transcendence of difference through mutual absorption; for dissolution of boundaries; for overcoming estrangement between self and other; for the soulful intermingling of self and world.

(NOTE: This text is from an artist statement composed by Char Davies for the Transfigure exhibition)

results.title: BabaKiueria
results.creator_credit: Don Featherstone, Julian Pringle, Geoffrey Atherden and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
‘BabaKiueria’ takes a satirical look at black-white relations in late twentieth century Australia, with a comic depiction of a racial role reversal. In documentary (or ‘mockumentary’) style, the film’s presenter investigates white lives in the fictitious land of ‘BabaKiueria’ (‘Barbeque Area’), where white people are a minority, living under black laws and suffering from discriminatory practices and attitudes held by the black majority. Written by Geoffrey Atherden (‘Mother and Son’, ‘Grass Roots’), the film was awarded a United Nations Media Peace Prize in 1987.
Stars Michelle Torres, Bob Maza, Kevin Smith, Cecily Polson, Tony Barry.

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This film is an excerpt from a family trip to Los Angeles and Universal Studios in Hollywood. Some parts of this film have an occasional hair in the gate.

The opening scenes of the film appear to depict a studio tour of the backlot of Universal Studios. We see a steam train departing from a platform with the signage “Ridgeway Elevation 3820”. There is a wild west show at the Silver Slippery Saloon, and shots of what could be Falls Lake with what appears to be the house from ‘Psycho’ in the background. We see Frankenstein’s monster feign strangling a suspecting Val Jellay.

Out in the streets of Los Angeles and Hollywood in particular, the film shows the Capitol Records tower as well as Hollywood Palace signage, buildings, and the Crown Derby Coffee Shop sign.

Street scenes, possibly on the Universal Studios backlot, reveal gothic architecture as well as buildings with Doric and Corinthian columns.

We see Maurie Fields and a friend sitting outdoors beside a tennis court which could possibly be a part of a hotel or resort.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlight
00:02:27:00 buildings along what could possibly be Universal Studios backlot

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in the Philippines, showing Manila street scenes and a sightseeing trip to the outskirts.

The film opens with scenes of a bamboo hut with a thatched roof set at the base of a hill. The hut appears to be a shop set up for tourists. It sells batik style clothing, and there is a sign post reading “Fiesta Batik Welcome”. There is a rudimentary brick church alongside the shop. We see Val Jellay walk down a dirt path past the church to join the other tourists on the bus.

Back at the hotel or resort, the film shows a swimming pool, umbrellas, sun lounges and a lifesaving ring with the inscription “Regency Manila”.

There is a road trip through the congested streets of Manila revealing colourful Jeepnies, Kalesas (horse drawn carriages), Volkswagen Beetles, a Kombi Van, taxis and local buses. We see street signs reading “Tokyo”, “Joy Mart” and “Gamma import-export” with the phone number.

Maurie takes us across the river and we see what could be the art deco Quezon Bridge which spans the Pasig River in Manila.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:14:00 bamboo hut/shop at base of hill
00:00:17:00 Fiesta Batik sign
00:00:21:00 bamboo hut/shop with Val in kaftan
00:00:32:00 brick church
00:01:28:00 streets lined with Volkswagen Beetles

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

Some of the footage is underexposed with a hair in the gate in some sections.

The film opens with scenes shot from a tourist boat trip through the Khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok Thailand. Along the way of the canals and river, we see tropical water plants lining either side of the narrow khlongs, traditional and motorised canoes, and square, fishing bag-nets. There are scenes of crumbling wooden stilt houses, river boats, colourful river ferries, longtail boats and Buddhist shrines. A stop-over includes scenes of tourists (possible family) riding a water buffalo.

Back on board there is beer and food served amidst an atmosphere of jolly tourist bonhomie. The beautiful Val Jellay drinks her beer in the “magic hour”.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlight:
00:02:00:00 Val Jellay on board the boat

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snippet from a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

Some of the footage is grainy and underexposed with some very unstable handheld sequences.

The film opens with a Bangkok street scene of a man holding a python wrapped around his arms and neck. We are then taken to the Grand Palace in the Phra Nakon district of Bangkok. The Grand Palace has been the official residence of the Kings of Siam (Thailand) since 1782. The King, his court, and his royal government were based on the grounds of the palace until 1925.

We see the grounds and buildings that comprise the palace, including Wat Phra Kaew (the Temple of the Emerald Buddha), Chakri Maha Prasat Hall, the Belfry and Hor Phra Monthian Dharma. We see the beautiful glazed tiles and gold leaf facade of Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). We see tourists taking photos and wandering around the site and there is scaffolding surrounding what could be Phra Siratana Chedi.

A very colorful Val Jellay, wearing a Kaftan style dress, poses on stairs leading to the entrance of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. She entertains her son and the camera operator while she strikes various traditional Thai-style dance poses.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Some of the footage is grainy and underexposed with some very unstable handheld sequences.

The film opens with a Bangkok street scene of a man holding a python wrapped around his arms and neck. We are then taken to the Grand Palace in the Phra Nakon district of Bangkok. The Grand Palace has been the official residence of the Kings of Siam (Thailand) since 1782. The King, his court, and his royal government were based on the grounds of the palace until 1925.

We see the grounds and buildings that comprise the palace, including Wat Phra Kaew (the Temple of the Emerald Buddha), Chakri Maha Prasat Hall, the Belfry and Hor Phra Monthian Dharma. We see the beautiful glazed tiles and gold leaf facade of Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). We see tourists taking photos and wandering around the site and there is scaffolding surrounding what could be Phra Siratana Chedi.

A very colorful Val Jellay, wearing a Kaftan style dress, poses on stairs leading to the entrance of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. She entertains her son and the camera operator while she strikes various traditional Thai-style dance poses.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.
description_for_label:
This film is a snippet from a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

Some of the footage is grainy and underexposed with some very unstable handheld sequences.

The film opens with a Bangkok street scene of a man holding a python wrapped around his arms and neck. We are then taken to the Grand Palace in the Phra Nakon district of Bangkok. The Grand Palace has been the official residence of the Kings of Siam (Thailand) since 1782. The King, his court, and his royal government were based on the grounds of the palace until 1925.

We see the grounds and buildings that comprise the palace, including Wat Phra Kaew (the Temple of the Emerald Buddha), Chakri Maha Prasat Hall, the Belfry and Hor Phra Monthian Dharma. We see the beautiful glazed tiles and gold leaf facade of Wat Phra Kaew (Temple of the Emerald Buddha). We see tourists taking photos and wandering around the site and there is scaffolding surrounding what could be Phra Siratana Chedi.

A very colorful Val Jellay, wearing a Kaftan style dress, poses on stairs leading to the entrance of the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. She entertains her son and the camera operator while she strikes various traditional Thai-style dance poses.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.
